Description: 
AC2 overall, underside is AC 4
SA: Squirt Acid, +1d4 damage

DESCRIPTION: The anhkheg resembles a long, insect with a natural beige or brown armor covering it's body. It can have anywhere from 12-18 legs, depending on its size and its head sport two sensitive antennae and two soulless eyes guaranteed to put the chill in anyone that just spend their last BP's improving their parley skill.

COMBAT/TACTICS: The creature burrows through the earth like a ravenous earthworm, it hunts its prey like a ravenous wolf, but fortunately it has all the strategy of a ravenous cockateal. Anhkhegs are mindless eaters and although they have a great natural trap (they burrow down leaving their antennae on the surface for a surprise attack made 7 in 8 times), they often place their traps in odd places: beneath outhouses, under lakes, inside graves or across well-traveled wagon paths. Many an anhkheg has set its antennae out only to have a fast-traveling wagon trample them causing the creature a great deal of pain. Fortunately, for the creature, it's too stupid to remember the pain very long.
It is also fortunate that the creature has little patience and usually changes it's location every 1d20 minutes or so. In it's own tiny mind it never seems to find the "right" spot, even if the spot gives it a steady supply of fat halflings or blind, overweight, elderly people. When the creature does manage to catch something, it continues to grip it in its mandible and drip digestive enzymes on it for 1d4 additional points of damage. The creature will continue the dripping until the victim escapes or is completely dissolved. A Bend Bars/Lift Gates roll at 50% of the victims normal roll is required to escape. If the creature dies, it instantly lets go and the acid stops. 

The anhkheg's most devastating attack is its acid spit. It can use the spit once every six hours and target a creature up to 30' away. Creatures struck take 8-32 points of damage and their possessions must make a saving throw vs. acid attack or be ruined. The creature will use this attack if it is brought below half it's total hit points. Unfortunately, the creature cannot count, so it is 50% likely to use the spit if struck for 1 point of damage or more at any time.

HABITAT/SOCIETY: Anhkhegs are nature's dumbest insect. They play the lottery and would smoke if their gargantuan limbs could support a cigarette, if in fact hold cigarettes or if cigarettes existed when the Anhkhegs did and if in fact they could acquire them by law.

ECOLOGY: Anhkheg females lay a brood of 10-100 eggs, but fortunately she quickly forgets what they are and usually steps on most of them. The male then fertilizes the eggs, forgets what he's doing there and eats some of them. Anhkheg mating rituals are often an uncomfortable process where both the male and female forget their part and attempt pathetic displays at finishing the ritual early, checking lottery numbers or attempting to smoke cigarettes. They are called Tony's Bane after the sage that refused to catalogue them for many years. Shortly after he completed his work he was killed by an anhkheg who attempted to smoke him.

YIELD: 
Medicinal: Anhkhegs taste nothing like chicken, but they are edible. An Anhkheg can provide sustenance for 10 people per hit die for 1 day.
Spell Components: Nil
Hide/Trophy Items: Farmers hate these idiot insects and will reward any adventurer that manages to kill one.
Treasure: Nil
Other: Bragging about the slaying of an anhkheg in a setting with fellow adventurers is consider a social faux paux and the individual will be ridiculed behind his back.

AKA: Ant Bastard, Burrowing Death Beast, Tony's Bane
HACKFACTOR: 9
E.P. VALUE: 300 per hit die
CLIMATE/TERRAIN: Underground, Agricultural, Temperate
FREQUENCY: Rare
ORGANIZATION: Solitary

Crayfish, Giant: Living on the bottom of very deep, wide rivers, they
feed almost exclusively on bottom-dwelling fish and non-buoyant
dwarves. They spend most of their time hunting and sometimes
compete with local fishermen.

Crayfish, Giant: This small, freshwater lobster will also ambush its prey
(-2 to opponent's surprise roll). It rushes out of the river, seizing its prey
(2-12 damage) and dragging it back to its lair. It is unlikely to attack
PCs unless they are stupid enough to swim near its lair.

Crayfish, Giant: Considered a great delicacy by other species, when word gets out that a Giant Crayfish is near, the area will become rife with hunters in 2d6 days. Some of the hunters will include Dragon Turtles, Giant Snapping Turtles, Merrows, Giant Otters, Gar, Giant Pike, Storm Giants and especially Nixies.

Dark Seether
DESCRIPTION: Dark Seethers are giant mushrooms that grow rapidly
out of any dead flesh. They are flesh-colored and sometimes bear
groups of spots that vaguely resemble the person they consumed.
COMBATITACTICS: Dark Seethers cannot attack in the classic
sense. If anyone approaches a Dark Seether within 20', they are 99%
likely to become covered with the tiny spores filling the air all around

them, and will breathe them into their lungs. While seemingly harmless at first, should the pc die with these spores still on him mushrooms will instantly begin to sprout and begin consuming his corpse. The mushrooms will not stop growing until all flesh is consumed, approximately 4-7 days later. The spores can be removed by bathing the body and equipment in alcohol or by casting a Neutralize Poison on the victim.

﻿SD: +2 or better weapon required to hit.

Air: Appearing as amorphous. shifting clouds or whirlwinds of intense power, Air Elementals speak in high-pitched shrieks that sound like a tornado or the low moans of a midnighr storm. Their personality ﻿are extremely flitty. There are Air Elementals who can take the rough forms of various flying creatures as well.

﻿Air: In aerial battles (when both combatants are airborne), Air Elemental get +1 to hit and +4 damage. The most feared power of an Air Elemental is its whirlwind, which looks like an inverted cone 10 feet wide at the bottom and 30 feet wide at the top. The greater the Hit Dice, the taller the cone (8HD is 40', 12HD is 60' and 16HD is 80'). A whirlwind lasts for one melee round, those hit by it are swept up and killed if they have under 3HD, otherwise rhey take 2-16 points of damage. If blocked by overhead obstructions, the damage is 1-8 and the whirlwind kills all creatures 2HD and under that it hits. An Air Elemenral can use this special attack once a day.

Earth: These creatures appear as humanoids made from dirt, stones, precious metals and/or gems. They have cold, expressionless faces and two eyes that sparkle like brilliant, multi-faceted gems. Their voices are the silence of deep tunnels, the rumblings of earthquakes and the grinding of stone. Their personalities are dull and
stubborn.

﻿COMBATITACTICS: Earth: Relentless but slow, Earth Elementals can travel through solid rock, but can never go through bodies of water (though they can go under or around them). Earth Elementals will always fight on the ground and their fists do 4-32 points of damage to﻿ any creature standing on the ground. Earth Elementals make effective on siege monsters, as they do great damage to structures. If forced to fight in the air or water, Earth Elementals get -2 damage per die (minimum of 1 point per die).

Fire: Fire Elemenrals appear as tall sheets of flame with two arm-like appendages on either side. The entire body of a Fire Elemental flickers and its eyes are two glowing patches of brilliant blue flame. The voice of a Fire Elemental can be heard in the crackle and hiss of a large fire. Their personalities are incredibly hot-tempered.

Fire: Fire Elemenrals attack savagely, burning crcarurcs for 3-24 points of damage. Any object struck by the elemental must save vs. spell at -2 or immediately begin to burn. Fire Elemenrals cannot cross water or non-flammable liquids.

Water: Appearing as a crested wave with two crested waves as arms,two green orbs of water serve as the elemental's eyes. Their voices can be heard in the crashing waves on rocky shores and the howl of an ocean gale. Water Elementals are incredibly moody, changing their tune from one minute to the next.

Water: Preferring to fight in large bodies of water, Water Elementals cannot fight more than 60 yards from the water rhey were conjured from and 1 point ofdamage per die (minimum of 1) is subtracted from their rolls when fighting outside of water. However, the huge wave- like arm of the Water Elemental can do 5-30 points of damage. Water Elementals can also flip a ship equal to their Hit Dice or less in tons and larger ships will be slowed according to ihe ratio of tonnage.

﻿DESCRIPTION: Giant Gar are gargantuan fish with long toothy maws perfectly suited swallowing prey. They only large, deep lakes or rivers they are freshwater creatures. Gar swallow prey whole on a 20 if the victim is man size or smaller. Creatures swallowed have a 5% cumulative chance of dying each melee round. \nOnly thar have dagger-sized weapons or smaller can cut their way out. Swallowed victims must infleict damge equal to 25% of the Gar's maximum hitpojnts to get free. Puncturing attacks against the gar have a 20% chance of also damaging the swallowed victim. Gar usually swim away once have swallowed a victim. Unfortunately, rhe victim will need to make a system shock roll (in addition to surviving the 5% chance of dying) to the pressure depth after 3 rounds.\n

Suprise 3 in 6

Gelatinous Cube
DESCRIPTION: In their normal form, Gelatinous Cubes resemble large cubes of nearly transparent gelatin. They may have strange objects floating inside their bodies. 

COMBATITACTICS: A Cube surprises victims 5 times out of 10. I t will either wait for a creature to blunder into it or wait to attack when a victim is near. Anyone struck must save vs. poison or become paralyzed for 5-20 rounds. Paralyzed victims are drawn into the Cube's mass to be slowly digested. Any inorganic materials will stay inside the Cube for weeks before being cast out. The Geladnous Cube is immune to cold damage, but if it misses a save it is slowed by 50% and takes 1-4 points of damage. All Gelatinous Cubes are immune to electricity, fear, hold spells, paralyzation, polymorph and sleep-based attacks. 

HABITATISOCIETY: Gelatinous Cubes are not intelligent, and instinctively want nothing more than to ear and to survive. These strange organisms are most often encountered in underground cavern or dungeon settings, where they find an odd array of things to eat. The Cube is not a picky eater, and will gather in all sorts of animal, vegetable and mineral items.

MR :0
Move :6

Type :Monster

﻿DESCRIPTION: Ghasts are Ghoul-like undead who reek of carnon, which helps to distinguish rhem from rheir Ghoulish brethren. 

COMBATITACTICS: Usually found with Ghouls, Ghasts look exactly the same as Ghouls, 
except hat they exude a carrion stench in a 10-foot radius. All those in the radius must save vs. ooison or become nauseated and attack at -2 to-hit. Due to their similarity to Ghouls. Ghasts paralyze by touch (the touch of a does affect elves). Ghast paraIyzation lasts 5-10 rounds or until negated by a cleric with a Remove Paralys~s or similar spell. Although they are similar to Ghouls in many respects, turning Ghasts is much harder. They take double damage From cold iron, but protection from Evil does nor keep them at bay unless it is used in conjunction with cold iron.

The touch of a ghoul causes paralyzation unless save versus paralyzation is made in all except elves. Lasting d6+2 rounds.

DESCRIPTION: Common Ghouls are undead humans who feed on the flesh ofcorpses. They are vaguely recognizable as the humans chey oncc were, but have become horribly disfigured. Ghouls have long, forked tongues, sharp, elongated teerh and strong claws. All Ghouls look vaguely similar and may continue to wear the tattered remains of wharevcr clothes they had in life. Ghouls are slobbering, flesh-earing maniacs, bur they hunt with an evil cunning. Lacedons arc aquatic Ghouls and alhtough they have webbing between rheir fingers and toes, rhey are in every way just like Ghouls. 

COMBAT/TACTICS: While Ghouls feast only on dead flesh, they have no problem wirh killing something to make it edible. Breaking vials of holy water in the path of Ghouls will cause them to hesitate one round, then jump over or run around it. 

Common: Ghouls attack en masse, swarming over prey and digging in with their filthy claws and hiring with rheir fangs. Their touch paralyzes humans and demi-humans (except elves) unless a save vs. paralyzation is . . made. Paralysis lasts for 3-8 rounds or until negated by a cleric. Any human or demi-human (except elves) killed by a Ghoul becomes one unless Blessed or completely devoured. Ghoul packs are completely fearless and will attack until destroyed. Ghouls are immune to Sleep and Charm spells. Clerics can turn them, while a Protection from Evil keeps them completely at bay.
Creature.sSpecialAttack: if hit save vrs paralyzation or paralyzed for 1d6+2 rounds

8 hp per head, lose one head attack per 8 hp damage\n

﻿DESCRIPTION: Hydra are immense, dragon-like reptilian creatures with multiple heads. For each Hit Die, the Hydra will have one head. Hydra are usually gray-brown to dark brown in color with light yellow or ran underbellies. Their eyes are amber and their teeth are yellow-white. Hydra are not known for dental hygiene.

Common Hydra: These Hydra have 5-12 heads. Their bite damage depends upon the number of heads as follows: 

Heads Damage Heads Damage 
5 1-6 9 1-8 
6 1-6 10 1-8 
7 1-8 11 1-10 
8 1-8 12 1-10
8 hp per head, lose one head attack per 8 hp damage\n

Description: ﻿The idol is actually a juggernaut. It an roll over victims (inflicting 10d10 points f damage) or reach out in any direction eel heads, tentacles, pincers, and other forms to six foot range, doing so four each round and inflicting 2-12 points of damage in each such attack. This thing is able to turn sharply or reverse directions unless it first comes to a complete halt. For every ten feet it travels it can turn about three feet; it must travel 30 feet to make a 90 turn. It is also slow to start; in the round of animation it can move but ten feet per round, but gains 1" additional movement each round thereafter until its maximum 12" rate is achieved. (For example, in the ninth round of animation it moves at 9" rate. )\n

COMBAT/TACTICS: Owlbears are so ferocious and predictable in conibat, it is easy to taunt them inro craps, over cliffs and even into fighting orher monsters. If it moves, an Owlbear will be likely ro atrack it. 

Common Owlbear: These Owlbears attack prey on sight and always fight to the death (no morale check). If the Owlbear rolls a natural 18 or better with a claw, the victim is dragged into a hug for 2-16 additional poinrs of damage (if the attack roll is a natural 20, it also gets a critical hit!). The victim can then be slashed with the Owlbear's beak automatically each round. A bend bars/lift gates roll can break rhe Owlbear's deadly grip. Owlbears fight until their hit points reach -5 before finally keeling over.

Special attack is disease. Injury by a rat causes disease has a 5% chance to cause disease.

Swim move is 6.

Special attack is disease. Injury by a rat causes disease has a 8.5% chance to cause disease.

COMBAT/TACTICS: All Rats like to line their nest with shiny objects. They are likely to steal rhese objects in lieu of attacking, as long as they are not hungry. Rats can tit through openings half their size by dislocating bones and squeezing their bodies through. 

Common Rat: Rats are scavengers, so they will eat almost any organic marerial. Unless controlled, driven by hunger or panicked by movemenr or bright lights, Rats are unlikely to attack. Common Rats can be distracted by throwing a significant amount of food in rheir direction. (This may encourage the Rats to follow the PCs, looking for more food. When no food is forthcoming and the Rats are hungry, tbey attack!) Common Rats fear fire, but can overcome this fear if hungry enough (Morale check with 25% bonus). Any injury delivered by a Rat has a 5% chance of infecting the vicrim with a random disease. 

Giant Rat: Giant Rats are wen larger rhan Large Rats and inflict more damage. They areslightly more aggressiveand their bites have an 8.5% chance of causing disease.

Rock Reptile
DESCRIPTION: These creatures have a lumpy, warty hide that resembles
rock. Rock Reptiles are about the size ofalligators, but they have
heads shaped roughly like a triceratops without horns.

COMBAT/TACTICS: Rock Reptiles will sit perfectly still in rubble or
rock and attempt to surprise a victim. Even close observation will fail
to note their presence 70% of the time. Victims struck will be dragged
back to the creature's lair to be devoured. Rock Reptiles prefer darkness,
but will occasionally come into the light if hungry enough. If sufficiently hungry, the creature can double its movement rate for two rounds (once per day) during an atrack.

﻿DESCRIPTION:A Salamander resembles a snake from waist down. It has humanoid torso, arms and a head like a wolf. wavy back, 11s body is covered protrusions down arms and behind ears. Salamanders immense heat and wield spears. On the Material Plane, these are encountered almost in volcanic regions.

﻿COMBAT: every attack inflicts 1d6 aditional points of heat damage, their tails can constrict opponents for 2d6 plus 1d6 heat damage per round. Flammable items within a 5ft radius burst into flames unless they succeed a saving throw vs. normal fire.

The upper body has AC5 while the lower body is AC3. It can only be struct by +1 or better magic weapons and immune to all fire, sleep, charm and hold spells. Cold related do +! point of damage per die.

Lightning scorpions (aka electric scorpions) are a smaller version of the large scorpion. They are found mostly in dry climes, but some have been discovered underground, and they tend also to be prevalent in magic-heavy areas.The lightning scorpion has an extremely hard blue-white carapace and bluish-green legs and pincers. The segmented tail is white, with a vicious glowing stinger on the end. There is an acrid smell associated with this scorpion, owing to its electrical nature. Little is known about the origin of this creature. Perhaps it is of extraplanar origin, or magical in nature. Its very fast recharge rate suggests a possible limited contact with the Plane of Air and its horrendous storms.Combat:Lightning scorpions cannot employ the grab attack that huge scorpions use, but their sting makes up for it. Every other round of combat the scorpion can dischargeits massive shocking attack. If the sting attack hits, it does 1 point of puncturedamage plus 3-36 points of electrical shock damage.Every time the scorpion is hit with a metal weapon, it conducts a 2-12 point shock to the wielder.Lightning scorpions are immune to electrical attacks and are actually healed an equivalent amount of hit points instead.Habitat/Society: Same as other scorpions.Ecology: Same as other scorpions.

Somewhere between Elves and Nymphs lie the Sidhe (pronounced "shee"). They are tall, slender and delicate, agile and beautiful. Sidhe resemble tall elves of exceptional beauty, usually pale of skin and light of hair. All have crystal blue eyes. They have their own tongue and speak Elven, common, and the musical language of the faire folk. If encountered, sidhe will most likely (75% of the time) be in the form of a pure white, shimmering woodland creature with crystal blue eyes.Combat: If possible, sidhe will avoid combat in favor of retreat. However, sidhe guarding of protecting an area or creature will fight to defend it. In its humanoid form, a sidhe will attacks with weapons, usually a long dagger or long bow for 1d6 points of damage. If encountered in its animal form, the sidhe attacks as a normal animal of that type, save that armor class and hit dice remain the same as in humanoid form. Sidhe gain a +2 bonus on surprise rolls because of their keen senses. They move silently and can blend in with foliage (in humanoid form) so as to be 70% undetectable. Sidhe in animal form are 90% undetectable in winter and 20% undetectable the rest of the year.Sidhe have a natural magic resistance of 50%, infravision to 60 feet, and can choose from among the following abilities 2x per day: Entangle, Pass Without Trace, Speak with Animals, Hallucinatory Forest, Plant Door.Habitat/Society: Sidhe live in tree cities that are protected from intruders by powerful illusions and misdirection spells that lead others away from or around their land. They are rarely found anywhere but in the deepest woods. A sidhe will never initiate contact with a human. Sidhe live for approximately 750 years, maturing at about the same rate as elves. At the end of adolescence, the sidhe goes into the woods in search of her animal spirit. This is accomplished when the sidhe comes upon an animal that is dying of natural causes (bear, wolf, deer, hawk, rabbit and squirrel are most common). She cradles the dying creature in her amrs and sings to it until it passes on. As a reward for the comfort the sidhe brings to the animal's last moments, a part of its sould is passed into the sidhe, giving her the ability to transform herself into a shimmering white animal of that type.Ecology: Sidhe, like most good creatures of the faerie race, maintain the balance of nature within their territory and abhor those who would destroy it.

DESCRIPTION: Green Slime resembles green-colored slime. It is a srrange plant thar does nor move, but instead falls when it senses vibration.

﻿COMBAT/TACIIC~:This plant drops on whatever it senses underneath it. It will slowly turn a victim into Green Slime. It cannot eat through metal quickly, eating through plate mail in 1 melee rounds and lighter armors in less time. It takes one hour to eat through an inch of wood but dissolves flesh upon contact. Green Slime cannot eat through glass. 

Victims caught without protection by Green Slime will be turned into Slime themselves in 1-4 rounds. slime can be scraped off quickly (if the scraper is also discarded quickly). A Cure Disease spell will kill Green Slime, but most
spells do not affect it at all. Only spells and effects involving fire or
cold will harm it, although such attacks also damage the victim.

Snake Venom Table

Roll To-Save Damage Per Effect-Time
1-4 +3 debilitating for 2d8 days - 1d4 turns
5-6 +2 death - 1d4+1 rounds
7-11 +1 1d4-2 points round 2d6 rounds
12-14 none 1d4-1 points round 1d6 rounds
15-16 -1 debilitating for 1d4 days - 2d4 rounds
17-18 -2 debilitating for 1d12 days - 1d4 rounds
19 -3 death - 1 round
20 -4 death plus 1d6 points - instant

Giant Venomous Snake: Giant Venomous Snakes are enormous varieties
of Venomous Snakes. Their poison causes death in one round if
the victim fails a save vs. poison and some snakes s t i l l cause 3-18 points
of damage to those who make their saving throw. Giant cobras can mesmerize prey just like bird charmers. They can eat an entire goat or
a demi-human up to the size of a halfling or gnome. Some varieties of
Giant Weasels hunt these creatures - giants who live in tropical regions
consider them a delicacy.

Stirge
DESCRIPTION: Common and Humming Stirges are blood drinkers.
Both varieties have pincher-like legs used ro land on victims and a needle-
like beak that they use to jab an artery and drink blood. Humming
Stirges have humming bird wings and are much faster, but very small.
COMBAT/TACTIC~: Common Stirge: Due to rheir ability to find and
attack weak points, Stirges attack as 4 Hit Dice monsters. Their noses inflict ld4-1 points ofdamage on a hit and then drain 1-4 points every
round thereafter. When a Stirge drains 12 points of blood, it is bloated
and flies away to digest.
If anyone other than the victim attempts to strike a Stirge, he must roll
against the AC of the victim at -2 (in addition to his normal attack
roll). If he succeeds, he avoids hitting the victim as well as the Stirge.
If he fails, he hits the victim (whether he hits the Stirge or not).

DESCRIPTION: Giant Ticks of all varieties are larger versions o f the tiny
parasites. These creatures are blind, but use sensory pads on their feelers
to sense heat.

COMBAT/TACTICS: Blinding attacks do not work on Giant Ticks, but
flashes of heat from Pyrotechnics or like spells will cause them to reel
and hesitate for one round.

Common Giant Tick: When a warm-blooded creature comes within
ten feet ofany Giant Tick it leaps down from its tree to attack. Victims
struck suffer 1-4 points of damage, plus 1-6 poinrs of blood drain damage
each round thereafter. Once it has drained its own maximum
number of hit points in damage, the Giant Tick will drop off and crawl
away to digest its meal.
Any creature bitten has a 50% chance of contractinga fatal blood disease
from the bite (Each stage lasts 1-2 days, Stage One Virulence
Factor: 5. sympton~s: dizziness, low energy; Stage Two Virulence
Factor: 7, symptoms: tiredness, Fever, -I to Strength, Dexteriry and
Constitution; Stage Three Virulence Factor: 13, symptoms: bedridden,
sever fever: Stage Four Virulence Factor: 17, symptoms: death). Giant
Ticks can be removed with the application of fire, acid, lightning,
Fireballs or siege weapon fire. Contrary to popular human rumors,
Giant Ticks will not fall off if immersed in water and they can hold
their breath for up to 24 hours.

﻿DESCRIPTION: Ttolls ate a common and feared humanoid on Garweeze Wurld. They come in different sizes and shapes, but most share common traits. Trolls are "butt-ugly", with green, warty skin rhat is usually covered with sores of one kind or another. They have large, black eyes, short, bristly black hair, big claws and big teeth. 

Common Troll: Common Trolls usually look emaciated. They rarely have clothes, armor or weapons and are appear to he only slightly above animals in their degree of civilization. However, to those "in the know", these beasts have their own customs and culture.

﻿COMBAT/TACTICS:Trolls regenerate 3 hit points per round and can reattach any severed limb. They cannot regenerate damage from weapons that deliver burn damage, such as fire or lightning. With their claws, they are able to climb sheer cliffs wirh an 80% chance of success. Trolls have a poor sense of hearing, but a superior sense of smell. Unless otherwise noted, Trolls have 90-foot infravision. Common Troll: Most Common Trolls have never encountered someone they could not defeat and eat. When they are hungry, which is always, they rush out to attack, overwhelming anything in their path with their raw power. Common Trolls gain +2 to-hit and inflict +4 damage with each attack due to Strength.

SA: Poison, suprise 1-6 on d10

﻿COMBATITACTICS: Stupid and aggressive, Wyverns attack anything that looks even vaguely like food. It can bite for 2-16 points of damage and sting with its tail 
for 1-6 points of damage in the same round. Obviously, these attacks must be directed against separate opponents. Anyone struck by the tail must immediately save vs, poison or die. 

In the air, Wyverns can use their claws (each inflicting 1-6 points of damage) to snatch opponents, then bite or sting them - away from their bothersome fiiends. They emit little to no scent and surprise victims 6 in 10 times.

HABITAT/SOCIETY:Wyverns are solitary and only gather to mate. Their territories stretch 25 miles in every direction from their lairs. Very rarely, Wyverns work
with evil draeons. usuallv as pawns in a greater scheme. Crafty dragons have been known to set up entirely fake lairs and let PCs fight a Wyvern or two first, then close in for the kill once the group is weakened. 

Ecology: Wyverns like fresh meat and only ear carrion if desperate. They have no natural enemies, although most people do not like them. Even those in the W.W.S. (Wyvern Watcher's Society) admir that Wyverns are awful creatures and that they mainly joined the sociery to meer women. Like dragons, Wyvern body parts are useful to magic users, but the hide is too brittle to he cured into armor.
